prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Key science target: the H13CN and H13CO+ J=1-0 lines set position of LO. HCN and HCO+ J=1-0 and CS(2-1) are dense gas tracers of interest and simultaneously obsrvable, so these are targetted.
The width of the spectral windows is set so include some continuum and, in the case of the H13CO+(1-0) window, possible detections of SiO(2-1) line (a tracer of shocks between gas clouds and from protostars).
The main interest is the line fluxes of H13CN and H13CO+ J=1-0, so the channels are spectrally averaged to reduce the data rate. We request 8x smoothed to obtain channels of 12 km/s. If the lines are brighter than expected we leave room for more detailed kinematic studies, while we can still average the channels for the faintest lines to 25 km/s if necessary.
In baseband 3 (in the USB) we have a continuum window, which uses TDM mode - this is a continuum measurement in a weak line region, so no need for FDM and we can significantly reduce the data rate.

Based on observations of Arp220, NGC6240 and other (U)LIRGs we expect the dense gas and 3mm continuum to be compact, on the order of an arcsecond.
We request lower than maximum possible angular resolution to increase flux sensitivity over target with all of the H13CN/H13CO+ 1-0 line flux expected to line within one or two beams. This resolution also uses a baseline <2km, so keeps the science goal standard science while being sufficiently high to allow for kinematic studies of the bright HCN and HCO+ lines.
If the lines emission is more extended than expected, the source may be cleaned with a larger beam for the H13CN and H13CO+ 1-0 line detection. Even in this case the LAS is still expected to be <2''.

Our key science target is the observation of H13CN(1-0) and H13CO+(1-0), so the S/N in these lines and the dynamic range drives sensitivity requirements.
The continuum flux has been estimated from interpolation of photometric SEDs. Line peak fluxes and FWHMs estimated from single dish HCN(1-0) observations combined with conservative estimates of the HCN(1-0)/H13CN(1-0) line ratio, based on our studies of Arp220 and NGC6240. HCN and HCO+ 1-0 will easily detected in any observations with a clear H13CN(1-0) line detection. CS and SiO J=2-1 are secondary, opportunity, science goals and so do not drive the requested rms. CS(2-1) will be detected in any observations with a clear H13CN(1-0) line detection, while detections or non-detections of SiO(2-1) are informative thenselves.
A S/N of 10 at the line peak allows for not only a detection but also a characterisation of the 13C isotopologue lines. With line FWHMs150-200 km/s, channels of 25 km/s are expected to be sufficient to characterise the lines.

Key science target: the H13CN and H13CO+ J=1-0 lines set position of LO. HCN and HCO+ J=1-0 and CS(2-1) are dense gas tracers of interest and simultaneously obsrvable, so these are targetted.
The width of the spectral windows is set so include some continuum and, in the case of the H13CO+(1-0) window, possible detections of SiO(2-1) line (a tracer of shocks between gas clouds and from protostars).
The main interest is the line fluxes of H13CN and H13CO+ J=1-0, so the channels are spectrally averaged to reduce the data rate. We request 8x smoothed to obtain channels of 12 km/s. If the lines are brighter than expected we leave room for more detailed kinematic studies, while we can still average the channels for the faintest lines to 25 km/s if necessary.
In baseband 3 (in the USB) we have a continuum window, which uses TDM mode - this is a continuum measurement in a weak line region, so no need for FDM and we can significantly reduce the data rate.

Based on observations of Arp220, NGC6240 and other (U)LIRGs we expect the dense gas and 3mm continuum to be compact.
We request lower than maximum possible angular resolution to increase flux sensitivity over target with all of the H13CN/H13CO+ 1-0 line flux expected to line within one or two beams. This resolution also uses a baseline <2km, so keeps the science goal standard science while being sufficiently high to allow for kinematic studies of the bright HCN and HCO+ lines.
If the lines emission is more extended than expected, the source may be cleaned with a larger beam for the H13CN and H13CO+ 1-0 line detection..
In this case we also have an LAS from CO isotopologue and millimetre continuum observations from the 230GHz observations of Sakamoto+2006.

Our key science target is the observation of H13CN(1-0) and H13CO+(1-0), so the S/N in these lines and the dynamic range drives sensitivity requirements.
The continuum flux has been estimated from interpolation of photometric SEDs. Line peak fluxes and FWHMs estimated from single dish HCN(1-0) observations combined with conservative estimates of the HCN(1-0)/H13CN(1-0) line ratio, based on our studies of Arp220 and NGC6240. HCN and HCO+ 1-0 will easily detected in any observations with a clear H13CN(1-0) line detection. CS and SiO J=2-1 are secondary, opportunity, science goals and so do not drive the requested rms. CS(2-1) will be detected in any observations with a clear H13CN(1-0) line detection, while detections or non-detections of SiO(2-1) are informative thenselves.
A S/N of 10 at the line peak allows for not only a detection but also a characterisation of the 13C isotopologue lines. With line FWHMs150-200 km/s, channels of 25 km/s are expected to be sufficient to characterise the lines.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Arp193
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Possible shadowing issues in compact array (Dec>+25?)

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Key science target: the H13CN and H13CO+ J=1-0 lines set position of LO. HCN and HCO+ J=1-0 and CS(2-1) are dense gas tracers of interest and simultaneously obsrvable, so these are targetted.
The width of the spectral windows is set so include some continuum and, in the case of the H13CO+(1-0) window, possible detections of SiO(2-1) line (a tracer of shocks between gas clouds and from protostars).
The main interest is the line fluxes of H13CN and H13CO+ J=1-0, so the channels are spectrally averaged to reduce the data rate. We request 8x smoothed to obtain channels of 12 km/s. If the lines are brighter than expected we leave room for more detailed kinematic studies, while we can still average the channels for the faintest lines to 25 km/s if necessary.
In baseband 3 (in the USB) we have a continuum window, which uses TDM mode - this is a continuum measurement in a weak line region, so no need for FDM and we can significantly reduce the data rate.

Based on observations of Arp220, NGC6240 and other (U)LIRGs we expect the dense gas and 3mm continuum to be compact, on the order of an arcsecond.
We request lower than maximum possible angular resolution to increase flux sensitivity over target with all of the H13CN/H13CO+ 1-0 line flux expected to line within one or two beams. This resolution also uses a baseline <2km, so keeps the science goal standard science while being sufficiently high to allow for kinematic studies of the bright HCN and HCO+ lines.
If the lines emission is more extended than expected, the source may be cleaned with a larger beam for the H13CN and H13CO+ 1-0 line detection. Even in this case the LAS is still expected to be <2''.
Wilson+2008 observed HCO+(4-3), with a spatial extent of 2'', strongly supporting out estimate of the LAS.

Our key science target is the observation of H13CN(1-0) and H13CO+(1-0), so the S/N in these lines and the dynamic range drives sensitivity requirements.
The continuum flux has been estimated from interpolation of photometric SEDs. Line peak fluxes and FWHMs estimated from single dish HCN(1-0) observations combined with conservative estimates of the HCN(1-0)/H13CN(1-0) line ratio, based on our studies of Arp220 and NGC6240. HCN and HCO+ 1-0 will easily detected in any observations with a clear H13CN(1-0) line detection. CS and SiO J=2-1 are secondary, opportunity, science goals and so do not drive the requested rms. CS(2-1) will be detected in any observations with a clear H13CN(1-0) line detection, while detections or non-detections of SiO(2-1) are informative thenselves.
A S/N of 10 at the line peak allows for not only a detection but also a characterisation of the 13C isotopologue lines. With line FWHMs150-200 km/s, channels of 25 km/s are expected to be sufficient to characterise the lines.

Key science target: the H13CN and H13CO+ J=1-0 lines set position of LO. HCN and HCO+ J=1-0 and CS(2-1) are dense gas tracers of interest and simultaneously obsrvable, so these are targetted.
The width of the spectral windows is set so include some continuum and, in the case of the H13CO+(1-0) window, possible detections of SiO(2-1) line (a tracer of shocks between gas clouds and from protostars).
The main interest is the line fluxes of H13CN and H13CO+ J=1-0, so the channels are spectrally averaged to reduce the data rate. We request 8x smoothed to obtain channels of 12 km/s. If the lines are brighter than expected we leave room for more detailed kinematic studies, while we can still average the channels for the faintest lines to 25 km/s if necessary.
In baseband 3 (in the USB) we have a continuum window, which uses TDM mode - this is a continuum measurement in a weak line region, so no need for FDM and we can significantly reduce the data rate.

Based on observations of Arp220, NGC6240 and other (U)LIRGs we expect the dense gas and 3mm continuum to be compact.
We request lower than maximum possible angular resolution to increase flux sensitivity over target with all of the H13CN/H13CO+ 1-0 line flux expected to line within one or two beams. This resolution also uses a baseline <2km, so keeps the science goal standard science while being sufficiently high to allow for kinematic studies of the bright HCN and HCO+ lines.
If the lines emission is more extended than expected, the source may be cleaned with a larger beam for the H13CN and H13CO+ 1-0 line detection. The LAS has been estimated from HCN(1-0) observations of Davies+2004.

Our key science target is the observation of H13CN(1-0) and H13CO+(1-0), so the S/N in these lines and the dynamic range drives sensitivity requirements.
The continuum flux has been estimated from interpolation of photometric SEDs. Line peak fluxes and FWHMs estimated from single dish HCN(1-0) observations combined with conservative estimates of the HCN(1-0)/H13CN(1-0) line ratio, based on our studies of Arp220 and NGC6240. HCN and HCO+ 1-0 will easily detected in any observations with a clear H13CN(1-0) line detection. CS and SiO J=2-1 are secondary, opportunity, science goals and so do not drive the requested rms. CS(2-1) will be detected in any observations with a clear H13CN(1-0) line detection, while detections or non-detections of SiO(2-1) are informative thenselves.
A S/N of 10 at the line peak allows for not only a detection but also a characterisation of the 13C isotopologue lines. With line FWHMs150-200 km/s, channels of 25 km/s are expected to be sufficient to characterise the lines.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
We propose Band 3, 0.75'' resolution observations of H13CN and H13CO+ in four galaxies in DeMoGas/HerCULES. These lines will complement the existing corpus of CO, 13CO, HCN, HCO+ and CS lines observed in these galaxies by breaking degeneracies in our models of the molecular gas. This will provide unique insights into the dense, star-forming gas at an unprecedented level of accuracy in a number of `standard' luminous infrared galaxies.
Furthermore, we will obtain the first measurements of the 3mm continuum is these galaxies, significantly aiding SED modelling of the dust. The spatial resolution will allow for detailed kinematic studies of the HCN and HCO+ in these galaxies, and for spatially resolved studies of the line and isotopologue line ratios, while the SiO observations will identify shocked regions. All of these data combined will allow for uniquely powerful studies of the star formation efficiency and dense gas mass fractions in these galaxies.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:keyword: Luminous and Ultra-Luminous Infra-Red Galaxies (LIRG & ULIRG)
